Name: Mercury
Discovered: Known to the ancients and visible to the naked eye.
Satellites: Mercery has no orbiting celestial bodies

Name: Venus
Named: Roman goddess of love and beauty.
Discovered: Known to the ancients and visible to the naked eye.
Atmosphere_Comp: 96% Carbon Dioxide, 3% Nitrogen, 1% Other Gases, Contains clouds of sulfuric acid.
Satellites: Venus has no orbiting celestial bodies
Visited: Mariner 2, 5, 10, Venera 4-16, Pioneer Venus Oribiter, Multiprobe, Vega 1-2, Galileo, Magelian, Cassini, Venus Express, MESSENGER, Akatsuki, IKAROS

Name: Earth
Named: The name 'Earth' is an English/German name which simply means the ground. It comes from the Old English words 'eor(th)e' and 'ertha'. In German it is 'erde'.
Discovered: Since the beginning of human's existance

Name: Mars
Discovered: Known to the ancients and visible to the naked eye.
Atmosphere_Comp: 95% Carbon Dioxide, 3% Nitrogen, 1.5% Argon, 0.5% Other Gases
Visited: 2001 Mars, Odyssey, Mars Express, MER-A 'Spirit', MER-B 'Opportunity', Mars Reconnaissance Oribter, Rosetta, Phoenix, Dawn, MSL Curiousity, Mars Orbiter Mission, MAVEN, ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter
Day: Slightly more than 1 Earth Day (24 hours, 37 minutes)

Name: Jupiter
Discovered: Known to the ancients and visible to the naked eye.
Atmosphere_Comp: 90% Hydrogen, 10% Helium, 1% Other Gases, Hydrogen is metallic in this high pressure state.
Satellites: Io, Europa, Ganymede, Callisto, Amaltheo, Himalia, Elara, Pasiphae, Sinope, Lysithea, Carme, Anake, Leda, Thebe, Adrastea, Metis, Callirrhoe, Themisto, Megaclite, Taygete, Chaldene, Harpalyke, Kalyke, Locaste, Erinome, Isonoe, Praxidike, Autonoe, Thyone, Hermippe, Aitne, Eurydome, Euanthe, Euporie, Orthosie, Sponde, Kale, Pasitihee, Hegemone, Mneme, Aoede, Thelxinoe, Arche, Kallichore, Helike, Carpo, Eukelade, Cyllene, Kore, Herse, S/2010 J 1, S/2010 J 2, Dia, S/2003 J 3, S/2003 J 4, S/2003 J 5, S/2003 J 9, S/2003 J 10, S/2003 J 12, S/2003 J 15, S/2003 J 16, S/2003 J 18, S/2003 J 19, S/2011 J 1, S/2011 J 2
Visited: Pioneer 10-11, Voyager 1-2, Galileo Orbiter, Galileo Probe, Cassini, Ulysses, New Horizons, Juno

Name: Saturn
Discovered: Known to the ancients and visible to the naked eye.
Atmosphere_Comp: 96% Hydrogen, 3% Helium, 1% Other Gases, Sulfur gives gas clouds a yellow cast
Satellites: Pan, Daphnis, Atlas, Prometheus, Pandora, Epimetheus, Janus, Aegaeon, Mimas, Methone, Anthe, Pallene, Enceladus, Tethys, Telesto, Calypso, Dione, Helene, Polydeuces, Rhea, Titan, Hyperion, Iapetus, Kiviuq, Ijiraq, Phoebe, Paaliaq, Skathi, Albiorix, S/2007 S 2, Bebhionn, Erriapo, Skoll, Siarnaq, Tarqeq, S/2004 S 13, Greip, Hyrrokkin, Jarnsaxa, Tarvos, Mundilfari, S/2006 S 1, S/2004 S 17, Bergelmir, Narvi, Suttungr, Hati, S/2004 S 12, Farbauti, Thrymr, Aegir, S/2007 S 3, Bestla, S/2004 S 7, S/2006 S 3, Fenrir, Surtur, Kari, Ymir, Loge, Fornjot

Name: Uranus
Named: Personification of heaven in ancient myth
Discovered: 1781 by William Herschel (was thought previously to be a star)
Atmosphere_Comp: 83% Hydrogen, 15% Helium, 2.5% Methane, Methane gas causes Uranus's blue color
Satellites: Titania, Oberon, Miranda, Ariel, Umbriel, Puck, Cordelia, Ophelia, Bianca, Cressida, Desdemona, Juliet, Portia, Rosalind, Belinda, Perdita, Caliban, Sycorax, Stephano, Prospero, Setebos, Trinculo, Ferdinand, Francisco, Mab, Cupid, Margaret

Name: Neptune
Atmosphere_Comp: 80% Hydrogen, 19% Helium, 1% Methane, Strongest winds in the solar system
Satellites: Naiad, Thalassa, Despina, Galatea, Larissa, S/2004 N 1, Proteus, Triton, Nereid, HalimedeSao, Laomedeia, Psamathe, Neso
